description:
Checking out the 70-tier releases from both Nvidia and AMD. We'll look at the RTX 5070, RTX 5070 Ti, RX 9070, and RX 9070 XT. We'll break down raw rendering performance, plus raytracing performance, and ai upscaling on both sides, plus talk current pricing on the scalper market to see what's gonna be the best fit for you.

@Hardwareunboxed video on Ray Tracing implementation on 36 games - https://youtu.be/DBNH0NyN8K8?si=y7uR0xvkMUXmQmKX
 
**The cards in today's video were provided by Nvidia and ASUS. All opinions are my own. Product links are affiliate links which means I get a small percentage if you make a purchase.**

comments.text:
It is not only the RayTracing. It is all the other technologies NVIDIA offers.
- DLAA/DLSS
- Reflex
- FG
- MFG

Not to mention they are working on Reflex 2 With New Frame Warp Technology.

But most important, you can run Minecraft with Shaders bigger than 256x256 and AMD canrds simlpy can't do this.

All jokes aside, NVIDIA continues to lead with real innovation, while AMD tends to play catch-up. Sure, the prices are steep, but you really do get what you pay for. Take 4x Frame Generation for example.
People complain about added latency, but I tested it myself and honestly couldn’t tell the difference between 2x and 4x. The delay was only around 2 milliseconds, and completely negligible during actual gameplay.

Instead of blaming the technology, blame the lazy developers who don't optimize their games anymore.

I saw this. My buddy recommended the 9070xt to me. He got it when it was 700-800 USD. Now I am looking around and anything even remotely close to MSRP is always out of stock without any hint of more stock incoming back at those prices even by retailers now. 

I found an OC version of a 5070Ti for about 930 USD. Cheapest in stock options I've been able to find for the 9070 XT is a base clocked one of 879. While I can outright buy the cards I prefer slow paying in which case the 5070 Ti I can pay over 1 year with no interest vs 9070XT is something I have to pay all at once. 

I feel like the performance and price difference especially since I will always try to max out my graphical settings, including RT, is worth it. Especially considering the non OC version is still 50-100 USD cheaper, making the gap even closer since the 9070XT I found is also base clocked. I also have a 5080 laptop I got at a steal and I personally feel like the most recent driver update and hotfix has not only eliminated some of the negatives of the 50 series I've been told about, but increased the performance a bit more too.

comments.text: I have had the opposite experience in terms of pricing and availability. I really wanted to support AMD and get a 9070 xt, but since launch day nothing has shipped anywhere for $600, online or in person even at Microcenters. They dropped for $650 ONE TIME on Newegg, or $700 a couple times, with $730 being the standard drops among Microcenter, Best Buy, and Newegg. They are somewhat a pain to get, but Best Buy has been restocking 5070 ti's for $750 a couple of times a day nearly every day for the last week online, and Microcenter has had a bunch of days where $750 models come in, though they are gone very quickly. Maybe if you can get a $700 xt with free shipping it's worth it, but the $700 drops I've seen have had $13 shipping charges, and now we're at best saving $37, more realistically $20 for the xt vs the ti. With how neck and neck the performance is, I'd take the one with better tech behind it for $20-$37 more. I wish the xt was able to stick to it's mystical $600 MSRP, but I don't think that's ever coming back. $650-$680 would be nice to see, but I will probably keep the 5070 ti I've ordered for $750 at this point

comments.text: Don't expect to actually get it for $200 less. AMD sent out a special refund to retailers to have units on sale for MSRP at launch, and that was done basically as a one-time launch promotion. The MSRP isn't meaningful long term. If you look at Newegg, you see them both for about $900 for the in-stock models, and I'd expect the shift to continue toward 5070 Ti being the more affordable card. What's really in shortage is TSMC 4 nm silicon (due to data center demand), and the 9070 XT actually uses roughly the same silicon area, from the same supplier, on basically the same process (though there are tweaks), as the 5080. The 9070 XT and 9070 are the high and low bins of the same main chip, like the 5080 and 5070 Ti (the non-Ti 5070 is an entirely different main chip using only about 70% as much silicon area). There are sensible production reasons for the 9070 XT to stay a little cheaper than the 5080 (6% smaller silicon area, cheaper last-generation VRAM giving 30% less bandwidth), but I wouldn't count on high-bin 9070 XT staying competitive in price and availability with the low-bin 5070 Ti.

comments.text:
@prevbean  the 9070 XT is objectively better performing in native res. But Ray Tracing can be a hassle. Also another note is DLSS4 is much more implemented in games than FSR4... Which is utter shite, but another factor to take in.
The 5070 ti does what its supposed to do, a little worse than 9070 XT, but you are secured DLSS and Frame Gen (and Ray Tracing if you use that..). 
Its a hard choice to choose.. Depending on what games you play.
If you play competitively, go for 9070 XT, since you wont be using any upscaling/frame gen or ray tracing.
If you play mostly solo games, then the 5070 Ti might be a more winning card in this matter, since sharpness and latency doesnt matter that much in solo games. As long as it looks pleasing enough, and gets enough fps that you are satisfied with.

comments.text:
Thanks for the review and sharing some of our recent AMD and NVIDIA graphics cards For clarity, the current pricing is noted below, and we would generally recommend that if comparing, you consider card class to card class, as more premium yards carry higher pricing for additional features/functions and design elements.

Some items not noted in this video include
Both AMD and NVIDIA this gen offer new phase change thermal pad for the GPU
Rear thermal pads for the backplate, many vendors are not offering any thermal pads for the backplate
Both have dual VBIOS designs
Both support 0dB operating fan modes
PCIe power LED notification for the cable connection regardless of legacy PCIe or 12x6
Decouple fan shroud design which means you can remove the fan shroud independent of the heatsink assembly
GPU Guard a enhancement to bonding the GPU die to the PCB for superior reliability/durability

PRIME cards
719 – 9070XT PRIME OC
939 – 5070Ti PRIME OC

*we offer a standard PRIME non OC model for $749

TUF GAMING cards
799 - 9070XT TUF GAMING OC
999 - 5070Ti TUF GAMING OC

9070
PRIME 9070 OC - 659
TUF GAMING 9070 OC - 709

5070
PRIME standard ( non OC ) - 549
PRIME OC - 699
TUF GAMING - 719
TUF GAMING OC - 739


*Please note that the power limit range for overclockers can considerably vary from vendor to vendor and model/series to model series.

Example is our 9070XT can have a default power limit of 335 vs another of 315 and the max can also vary 370 vs 347.  Base increase will slightly affect performance and the max limit can help extend OC margin.

Hope this helps whichever card you settle on.

comments.text:
@felixfiedler4982  Because we're basically at the end of Moores Law. In the early 2000s you could double the amount of transistors on a chip and keep the same die-size by shrinking the size of the transistors, but transistors can't really be made smaller anymore, so the only way to increase performance is to add transistors by increasing the chip size, this is why cards like the 4090 and 5090 exist. But even then we'll reach a point where we can't just keep making chips bigger and bigger, so we've basically just hit a point of performance stagnation that didn't exist before and won't improve until we find a new way to develop microchips or change how they work fundamentally.

I used a 2070 Super from 2019 to 2023 because it didn't make sense to get a new card for 1080p gaming if mine could still hit 144Fps @ high settings in all the games I played. A lot mid-range cards are still around that level of performance @ 1080p and are still relevant for people to buy.
